p: The layers representing current climates are in a resolution of 2.5 arc-minutes (~4.5 km 2 at the equator), which contained bioclimatic data from the 1950s to the present. To predict the distribution of species of Ceratophryidae in future climates, we used climate models with a resolution of 30 arc-seconds (0.93 x 0.93 = 0.86 km 2 at the equator) of the Canadian Centre for Climate Modelling and Analysis–CCCMA (CGCM4/CMIP5). Emission scenarios used were A2 and B2 [ 29, 30]. This was done to predict the distributions in reasonably optimistic (B2) and/or pessimistic (A2) scenarios of global climate change according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change—IPCC [ 31, 32].
